Exam Hacks

Fast Tricks to Convert Direct ⇄ Indirect Speech — Govt Exam Guide

Concise rules, quick mental shortcuts and 15+ PYQs with answers — practice these to save precious time in objective tests.

Core idea — what changes?

When shifting from direct to indirect speech, watch four things: Reporting verb (say, tell, ask), pronouns, time/place words, and verb tense. Use simple substitution patterns instead of heavy grammar memory.

Fast 5-step conversion method

  1. Identify reporting verb (said/told/asked) and whether it’s say (no object) or tell (has object).
  2. Remove quotation marks and make the reported clause a subordinate clause (use that for statements, if/whether or to/for for questions).
  3. Backshift the tense if the reporting verb is in the past: present → past, past → past perfect, will → would, can → could, shall → should. (Exceptions: universal truths stay same.)
  4. Change pronouns & time/place words (now → then, today → that day, here → there, yesterday → the day before, next week → the week after).
  5. Use correct reporting verb structure: use tell with object (He told me that...), ask with if/whether for yes/no questions, and ask + wh-word for WH-questions.

Quick tense backshift table

  • Present simple → Past simple (He said, "I live here." → He said that he lived there.)
  • Present continuous → Past continuous
  • Present perfect → Past perfect
  • Simple past → Past perfect
  • Will → Would, Can → Could, May → Might
  • Modals without past form (must) → had to / should (context-based)

Shortcut phrases (memorize these)

  • "He said, '...'." → "He said that ..."
  • "He said to me, '...'." → "He told me that ..."
  • Yes/No question: "Did she come?" → "He asked if/whether she had come."
  • WH-question: "Where do you live?" → "He asked where I lived."
  • Imperative: "Shut the door." → "He ordered me to shut the door."

Examples (Direct → Indirect)

Direct: She said, "I am reading a book now."

Indirect: She said that she was reading a book then.

Direct: He asked, "Do you like coffee?"

Indirect: He asked me if I liked coffee.

Direct: The teacher said, "Finish the exercise."

Indirect: The teacher told us to finish the exercise.

Direct: She said, "I have finished my work."

Indirect: She said that she had finished her work.

PYQs — Practice 18 sentences

Convert each to reported speech (Indirect). Mix of statements, WH and yes/no questions, commands and requests.

  1. Raj said, "I will come tomorrow."
  2. She said, "I saw him yesterday."
  3. He asked, "Are you leaving now?"
  4. My mother said to me, "Do your homework."
  5. They said, "We have won the match."
  6. She asked, "Where do you live?"
  7. He said, "I can help you."
  8. The officer said, "Submit the form by Friday."
  9. Rita said, "I am going to Delhi next week."
  10. He asked, "Did they finish the work?"
  11. She said, "I was planning to call you."
  12. Teacher said, "Who has done the assignment?"
  13. She said, "Don't make noise in the library."
  14. He said to her, "Please open the window."
  15. My friend said, "I had seen that movie before."
  16. The doctor said, "You must take this medicine."
  17. He said, "Tomorrow is a holiday."
  18. They asked, "Will you attend the meeting?"

(Answers follow — attempt first!)

Answer key — Indirect forms

  1. Raj said that he would come the next day.
  2. She said that she had seen him the day before.
  3. He asked if I was leaving then.
  4. My mother told me to do my homework.
  5. They said that they had won the match.
  6. She asked where I lived.
  7. He said that he could help me.
  8. The officer asked/told us to submit the form by Friday.
  9. Rita said that she was going to Delhi the following week/the week after.
  10. He asked if they had finished the work.
  11. She said that she had been planning to call me.
  12. The teacher asked who had done the assignment.
  13. She told us not to make noise in the library.
  14. He requested her to open the window / He asked her to open the window.
  15. My friend said that he had seen that movie before.
  16. The doctor said that I had to take that medicine / the doctor told me to take that medicine.
  17. He said that the next day was a holiday.
  18. They asked if I would attend the meeting.

Exam tips & quick checks

  • If reporting verb is present (says/asks), do not backshift tenses.
  • For commands use tell/ask/request + object + to + verb (e.g., "She told him to go.").
  • Yes/no questions → use if/whether. WH-questions keep the wh-word but remove question order.
  • Time words — memorize replacements: now→then, today→that day, yesterday→the day before, tomorrow→the next day/the following day.
  • Practice converting 20 lines daily; speed and pattern recognition beat deep grammar in objective exams.
